    Note

    Make sure the metadata is entered correctly before you upload the JSON file. It’s used to identify the CBOM data in the associated AQtive Guard tables.

  3. To upload the CBOM JSON file, either:

    • Click in the target area and select the file from your local system.
    • Drag and drop the file into the target upload area.

    The data will begin uploading automatically.

docs.title: CrowdStrike
docs.text: AQtive Guard can ingest scans from CrowdStrike and generate a cryptographic analysis of available data.

docs.title: CrowdStrike requirements
docs.text:
The minimum requirements for application or product support are:

  • CrowdStrike API client with the following Falcon API scopes:
    • Hosts (read)
    • Real time response (admin) (write)
    • Real time response (read, write)
  • Hosts you want to scan must be running a version of Windows or Linux that’s supported by the CrowdStrike sensor.

docs.title: Falcon module dependencies
docs.text:
Falcon customers require the following subscriptions to use the CrowdStrike integration:

  • Falcon Prevent
  • Falcon Insight XDR

docs.title: Supported platforms
docs.text:
• Windows
  • Linux

docs.title: Configure the CrowdStrike integration
docs.text:
To configure the CrowdStrike integration in AQtive Guard, you’ll need your CrowdStrike Base URL, Client ID, and Client secret. To obtain these:

  1. Log into your Falcon Console as a Falcon Administrator.
  2. Select Support, then API Clients and Keys. You can also search for API keys and select API Clients and Keys from the search results.
  3. Select Create API Client and specify a name and description.
  4. In the Scopes section, you’ll select the necessary scopes:
    • For ingesting hosts and applications - select Read next to both Hosts and Apps.
    • For deploying and running the AQtive Guard Filesystem Scanner:
      • Select Write next to Real time response (admin) and Real time response.
      • Select Read next to Real time response.
  5. Select Create and copy the Base URL, Client ID, and Secret values.

Tip

Make sure to copy the credentials and save them in a secure place. Once you close the window, they can’t be shown again. If you do lose access to the credentials, you can reset an API client’s Secret, edit the scopes that are associated with it, or revoke all access.

Log in to AQtive Guard to complete the following steps.

  1. Select Data sources from the main menu, then select Configure in the CrowdStrike panel.
  2. Paste the information you copied from CrowdStrike into the designated fields:
    • Your Base URL (into the Instance URL field).
    • Your API Client ID.
    • Your API Client secret.
  3. (Optional) Select Test Connection to check the connection to the CrowdStrike API.
  4. Select Submit to update the settings.

Note

Selecting Submit performs the same check as the Test connection button, in addition to verifying the client ID and secret are valid.

docs.title: Use
docs.text:
Once the integration is configured, you can trigger a CrowdStrike host ingestion.

This process:

  1. Pings the CrowdStrike API.
  2. Extracts the relevant data.
  3. Maps the data into the AQtive Guard format.
  4. Ingests the data into AQtive Guard for analysis.

Note

If the CrowdStrike settings aren’t configured, the ingestion options will be disabled.

docs.title: Trigger CrowdStrike ingestion
docs.text:
To ingest host data or application data from CrowdStrike:

  1. Select Data sources from the main menu, then select Details in the CrowdStrike panel.
  2. Enter a value in the Last seen hours field. This value filters connections to only hosts active in your specified time frame.
  3. Select:
    • Start hosts ingestion to trigger ingestion of the selected host data into AQtive Guard.
    • Start applications ingestion to trigger ingestion of application information for the selected hosts.

docs.title: View CrowdStrike ingestion data
docs.text: Once the ingestion is complete, any relevant data will begin populating. To find it, select Hosts from IT Assets and look for the CrowdStrike tag in the Data sources column.

docs.title: Trigger CrowdStrike scan
docs.text:
Follow these instructions to run a scan and ingest CrowdStrike data for analysis by AQtive Guard.

  1. Select Data sources from the main menu, then select Details in the CrowdStrike panel.
  2. In the Scans section, select Start Scan and configure the following:
    • Scan name - a default date and time stamp is provided. You can change this to any unique name.
    • Scan Settings Profile - the impact that the scan will have on your infrastructure. There are 3 options:
      • High impact - this will use a workload of 100%. There’s also no limit to the number of files that can be scanned per second, and the max file size is 1 GB.
      • Standard impact (default) - this will use a workload of 50%. The number of files that can be scanned per second is 10,000 and the max file size is 1 MB.
      • Low impact - this will use a workload of 5%. The number of files that can be scanned per second is 1,000 and the max file size is 512 KB.
    • Platform - select Linux or Windows.
    • Hostname (optional) - only scan hosts that contain the entered text in their name.
    • Host Activity (optional) - only scan hosts that were pinged within the Last X hours. The Estimated number of affected hosts section updates as you fill in the required fields.
  3. Select Start Scan to scan the selected hosts and ingest the data into AQtive Guard for analysis.

docs.title: View CrowdStrike scan data
docs.text:
Once you start a scan, you can see the progress in the Scans table. The table displays the following information:

  • Name - the scan name provided when configuring the scan.
  • Status - the status of a scan. The possible values are:
    • Pending - scan is in the scan queue.
    • In Progress - actively scanning.
    • Completed - scan has been successfully ingested into AQtive Guard.
    • Canceled - the scan has been terminated by user action.
  • Progress - the number of hosts scanned / total number of hosts selected.
  • Scan Start - the timestamp for when the scan started (MM/DD/YYYY HH:MM:SS AM/PM), based on the time zone set in your browser, with system time in UTC.
  • Scan End - the timestamp for when the scan is completed or stopped (MM/DD/YYYY HH:MM:SS AM/PM), based on the time zone set in your browser, with system time in UTC.
  • Duration - the length of time the scan was active.

You can view more information for a specific scan by selecting Details in the row of the scan you’re interested in. The Scan Results table appears, which displays the following:

  • IT Asset - the name of the asset.
  • Status - the status of the scan on the asset. The possible values are:
    • Pending
    • Scanning
    • Retrieval
    • Downloading
    • Success
    • Fail
  • Platform - the asset’s platform. This is either Linux or Windows.

Any successful asset scans will be also be shown in IT assets.

docs.title: Unlink the CrowdStrike integration
docs.text:
Unlink the CrowdStrike integration only if your organization needs to reconfigure or stop data sharing with CrowdStrike.

To unlink the CrowdStrike configuration:

  1. Select Data sources from the main menu, then select Details in the CrowdStrike panel.
  2. Select Unlink.

docs.title: PCAP
docs.text:
You can upload a PCAP file for analysis using the AQtive Guard API.

Refer to Getting started with PCAP upload in the AQG Network Analyzer guide for details.

docs.title: Qualys
docs.text: AQtive Guard can ingest scans from Qualys and generate a cryptographic analysis of available data.

docs.title: Qualys requirements
docs.text:
• Node LTS (20.14.0) or newer.
  • The Qualys Gateway URL you will connect to. Refer to Identify your Qualys platform.
  • A username and password for the Qualys admin account to be used for authentication.

docs.title: Configure the Qualys integration
docs.text:
Log in to AQtive Guard to complete the following steps.

  1. Select Data sources from the main menu, then select Configure in the Qualys panel.
  2. Enter the following information into the designated fields:
    • Instance URL - the location of the Qualys API.
    • Username - your username required to authenticate with the Qualys API.
    • Password - password associated with the username for authentication.
  3. (Optional) Select Test Connection to check the connection to the Qualys API.
  4. Select Submit to update the settings.

Note

Selecting Submit performs the same check as the Test connection button, in addition to verifying the username and password are valid.

docs.title: Use
docs.text:
Once the integration is configured, there are three types of Qualys ingestions available: Secrets, Certificates, and Handshakes.

Note

Only one type of ingestion can be active at a time.

All of these processes:

  1. Ping the Qualys API.
  2. Extract the relevant data.
  3. Map the data into the AQtive Guard format.
  4. Ingest the data into AQtive Guard for analysis.

Note

If the Qualys settings aren’t configured, the ingestion options will be disabled.

docs.title: Ingest Qualys secrets
docs.text:
To ingest secrets data from Qualys:

  1. Select Data sources from the main menu, then select Details in the Qualys panel.
  2. Select Start secrets ingestion to trigger the ingestion of secrets data into AQtive Guard.

docs.title: Ingest Qualys certificates
docs.text:
To ingest certificate data from Qualys:

  1. Select Data sources from the main menu, then select Details in the Qualys panel.
  2. Select Start certificates ingestion to trigger the ingestion of certificate data into AQtive Guard.

docs.title: Ingest Qualys handshakes
docs.text:
To ingest handshake data from Qualys:

  1. Select Data sources from the main menu, then select Details in the Qualys panel.
  2. Select Start handshakes ingestion to trigger the ingestion of handshake data into AQtive Guard.

docs.title: View Qualys data
docs.text:
Once the ingestion is complete, any relevant data will begin populating. To find it:

  • From IT Assets, select Hosts or Container images.
  • From Inventory, select either the Secrets, Certificates, or Handshakes tab, depending on the ingestion type.

Look for the Qualys tag in the Data sources column.

docs.title: Unlink the Qualys integration
docs.text:
Unlink the Qualys integration only if your organization needs to reconfigure or stop data sharing with Qualys.

To unlink the Qualys configuration:

  1. Select Data sources from the main menu, then select Details in the Qualys panel.
  2. Select Unlink.

docs.title: Getting started
docs.text:
AQtive Guard (AQG) is a comprehensive, centralized cryptographic management platform offering a unified view for Non-Human Identity (NHI) and Cryptography management. It empowers you to manage, strengthen, and adapt your IT systems and policies centrally from a single, unified platform. With a focus on long-term security and compliance, AQG will help you future-proof against emerging threats, including the potential impact of quantum computing.

This guide introduces the key components of AQG and how they work together. The following diagram illustrates the principal elements and data flow.

  1. Host Machines and Cloud Network: The AQG yanadump tool processes live network traffic in real time. Using cloud-native traffic mirroring, yanadump extends monitoring to cloud assets, enabling seamless coverage in hybrid environments. Learn more:
    • AQG Network analyzer
    • Getting started capturing live network traffic monitoring
    • GCP packet mirroring tutorial
  2. Data Sources: AQG offers powerful AQG sensors, for in-depth cryptographic analysis of filesystems, applications, and physical and virtual networks. It also integrates with a variety of external data sources to centralize your IT assets and crypto inventory. Learn more:
    • AQG Filesystem Scanner
    • AQG Java Tracer
    • AQG Network Analyzer
    • Qualys
    • CrowdStrike
    • CBOM
    • PCAP
    • AWS Key Management Service (KMS)
  3. Analysis: When AQtive Guard analyzes data, it evaluates detected cryptographic objects against the active rules. Learn more:
    • Rules
    • Network analyzer
  4. API: The AQG API enables integration and automation, and powers the AQG web UI. Learn more:
    • API reference
  5. UI: Provides a user-friendly interface for managing your cryptographic data. Learn more:
    • Dashboard
    • Inventory
    • IT assets
    • Issues

docs.title: (Cryptographic) Algorithm
docs.text: A sequence of computational instructions that performs specific (cryptographic) tasks.

docs.title: API (Application Programming Interface)
docs.text: A set of functions that enable different software components to communicate and transfer data.

docs.title: (AQtive Guard) API client
docs.text: The AQtive Guard API Client (cs-api) is a CLI program you can use to interface with AQtive Guard using its API. Its two main purposes are uploading traces created using the AQtive Guard sensors and launching an analysis in AQtive Guard.

docs.title: AQL (AQtive Guard Query Language)
docs.text: The SandboxAQ domain-specific language (DSL) designed for querying data, with queries processed and executed in the format of a KSQL table.

docs.title: Asymmetric cryptography
docs.text: Synonym: public key cryptography

docs.title: Augmented trace
docs.text: A trace file enhanced with additional details, such as cryptographic call sites.

docs.title: Authenticity
docs.text: A security property achieved through cryptographic methods that guarantees data is genuine, verifiable, and trustworthy. It provides confidence in the validity of a transmission, information, message, or its sender.

docs.title: Block cipher
docs.text: A cryptographic algorithm that maps blocks of fixed lengths to blocks of the same length such that for every output there is exactly one input.

docs.title: Brute-force attack
docs.text: An attack method of trying every possible value for a secret input, like a secret key or password, until the correct one is found.

docs.title: CCPA (California Consumer Privacy Act)
docs.text: A California law that gives residents rights over their personal data, including the right to know what information is collected, to have it deleted, and to opt out of its sale. It requires businesses to be transparent about their data practices and protect consumer privacy.

docs.title: Certificate
docs.text: A signed document, linking a public key to an identity. Common examples of an identity are a domain name, an email address, or a X.500 common name. Certificates usually also contain additional management data, like a validity period, a serial number, issuer identity, and potential extensions providing more context data.

docs.title: Certificate Authority (CA)
docs.text: A trusted organization that issues certificates to verified entities, such as websites or individuals, linking their identity to public keys. This allows the user to authenticate a communication partner using public key cryptography.

docs.title: CSR (Certificate Signing Request)
docs.text: A message sent from an applicant to a certificate authority (CA) in order to apply for a certificate.

docs.title: Collision
docs.text: A scenario where two distinct inputs to a cryptographic hash function produce the same output.

docs.title: Collision attack
docs.text: An attack that attempts to find two inputs to a cryptographic hash function that produce the same output.

docs.title: Computational infeasibility (Computationally infeasible)
docs.text: A task or calculation is considered computationally infeasible if it would require an unrealistically long time or computing resources to complete, making it practically impossible to achieve within a practical timeframe.

docs.title: Confidentiality
docs.text: A security property that guarantees data is not disclosed to users, processes, or devices unless they are authorized to access the information.

docs.title: Counter with CBC-MAC (CCM)
docs.text: A block cipher mode of operation that provides both confidentiality and authentication.

docs.title: CRL (Certificate Revocation List)
docs.text: A list of certificates that have been revoked by the issuing certificate authority (CA) before their scheduled expiration date. CRL certificates should no longer be trusted.

docs.title: Cryptographic call site
docs.text: A location in the code where cryptographic functions (such as encryption, decryption, or hashing) are invoked.

docs.title: Cryptographic key
docs.text: A typically short piece of data that is used in most cryptographic algorithms to perform their operations with. The key type depends on the algorithm and determines its confidentiality requirements. For example, secret keys and private keys must remain confidential, while public keys are intended to be shared.

docs.title: Cryptographically relevant quantum computer (CRQC)
docs.text: A quantum computer capable of breaking cryptographic systems used in real-world applications, which are deemed infeasible to break with conventional computers.

docs.title: Decryption
docs.text: The process of converting ciphertext back into plaintext, reverting encryption.

docs.title: Deprecated (cryptography)
docs.text: A cryptographic algorithm or key length that was previously approved for a specific application but is no longer recommended due to identified security weaknesses.

docs.title: Digital signature
docs.text: A value computed with a cryptographic process using a private key and appended to a data object to digitally sign it. The digital signature enables verification of the data object’s authenticity and integrity using the signer’s public key. A secure signature scheme guarantees the computational infeasibility of creating forgeries (refer to EUF-CMA).

docs.title: Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC)
docs.text: A type of public key cryptography.

docs.title: Encryption
docs.text: The process of transforming plaintext into ciphertext.

docs.title: Entropy
docs.text: A measure of randomness or unpredictability in data, often used in cryptography to ensure secure key generation and encryption.

docs.title: Existential Unforgeability under Chosen Message Attack (EUF-CMA)
docs.text: The standard security notion for a digital signature scheme. A scheme is EUF-CMA secure if it is computationally infeasible for an adversary to forge a valid signature, even when they can obtain valid signatures for messages they select or craft themselves.

docs.title: Filesystem scanner
docs.text: An AQtive Guard sensor that scans the filesystem for cryptographic artifacts, like cryptographic keys or certificates.

docs.title: Forward secrecy
docs.text: A property of cryptographic protocols that guarantees the secrecy of previously transmitted data remains protected, even if a private key is compromised.

docs.title: Galois/Counter Mode (GCM)
docs.text: A block cipher mode of operation that provides both encryption for confidentiality and authentication for data authenticity and integrity. It is widely used and recommended.

docs.title: GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation)
docs.text: A European Union regulation that sets strict guidelines on collecting, processing, and storing personal data, granting individuals more control over their data and requiring organizations to ensure privacy and security compliance.

docs.title: (Cryptographic) Hash function
docs.text: A core cryptographic building block that converts input data of arbitrary length into short, fixed-length outputs, known as a hash value or digest. A secure hash function ensures it is computationally infeasible to find two inputs that produce the same output collision, determine an input from its output, or to distinguish the output from random values.

docs.title: HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act)
docs.text: HIPAA, the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, is a U.S. federal law designed to ensure the privacy and security of patients’ health information. It sets standards for how healthcare organizations and their business associates handle, share, and protect sensitive medical data.

docs.title: Hardware Security Module (HSM)
docs.text: A physical computing device that safeguards and manages cryptographic keys and provides cryptographic processing. An HSM is or contains a cryptographic module.

docs.title: Integrity
docs.text: A security property that guarantees that data or a system are not (maliciously) altered.

docs.title: Java tracer
docs.text: An AQtive Guard sensor that records cryptographic operations in Java applications for analysis.

docs.title: Key agreement
docs.text: Synonym: key exchange.

docs.title: Key derivation
docs.text: The process of deriving a secret key in a non-reversible manner from shared information, at least some of which is secret.

docs.title: Key Derivation Function (KDF)
docs.text: A cryptographic algorithm that derives one or more secret keys from an input secret bit string of sufficient entropy, optionally incorporating additional context information.

docs.title: Key Encapsulation Mechanism (KEM)
docs.text: A set of three cryptographic algorithms (called key generation, encapsulation, and decapsulation) that can be used to establish shared secret keys over a public channel.

docs.title: Key establishment
docs.text: Synonym: key exchange.

docs.title: Key exchange
docs.text: A process that allows two parties to securely establish a shared secret key over a public channel in order to establish secure communications.

docs.title: Key management
docs.text: The process of creating, storing, distributing, and securely handling cryptographic keys throughout their lifecycle to protect sensitive data and ensure secure communications.

docs.title: Key pair
docs.text: Pair consisting of a private key and a public key. Used in public key cryptography.

docs.title: Key transport
docs.text: A procedure whereby one party (the sender) selects a value for the secret keying material and then securely distributes that value to another party or device (the receiver). Contrast with key exchange.

docs.title: Key wrapping
docs.text: A method of protecting secret keying material (along with associated integrity information) that provides both confidentiality and integrity protection when using symmetric-key algorithms.

docs.title: Legacy use
docs.text: Approval to continue using an algorithm or key length only in scenarios where legacy applications cannot be updated or replaced without unreasonable effort.

docs.title: Machine-In-The-Middle (MITM) Attack
docs.text: A Machine-in-the-Middle attack is a cyberattack where the attacker secretly relays and possibly alters the communications between two parties who believe that they are directly communicating. Historically, this class of attacks was known as a man-in-the-middle (MITM) attack. The term attacker in the middle is more common, although some prefer Machine-in-the-Middle or Mallory-in-the-Middle to retain the well-known acronym MITM and still using gender-neutral language.

docs.title: Message Authentication Code (MAC)
docs.text: Cryptographic data, created with a symmetric key, that is attached to a message and can be used to verify its integrity and authenticity using the same key.

docs.title: Mode of operation
docs.text: An algorithm for the cryptographic transformation of data that uses a block cipher.

docs.title: OCSP (Online Certificate Status Protocol)
docs.text: An interactive protocol used to verify the revocation status of a certificate.

docs.title: PCI-DSS (Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard)
docs.text: PCI DSS, the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard, is a set of security requirements designed to ensure the safe processing, storage, and transmission of cardholder data. It applies to all businesses and organizations that accept, process, or store payment card information.

docs.title: PKCS#11
docs.text: A standard defining cryptographic tokens, often used for smart cards and hardware security modules (HSMs).

docs.title: Post-quantum cryptography
docs.text: Cryptographic algorithms designed to resist attacks not only from classical but also quantum computers.

docs.title: Private key
docs.text: The secret part of a key pair that must be kept confidential. It’s used to perform operations in (public key) cryptographic algorithms such as decryption or signing.

docs.title: Public key
docs.text: The public part of a key pair. that does not need to be kept confidential and can be shared openly. It’s used to perform operations in (public key) cryptographic algorithms such as encryption or signature verification.

docs.title: Public key cryptography
docs.text: Cryptography that uses a key pair consisting of a private key and a public key to secure communications. Also known as asymmetric cryptography.

docs.title: Public Key Infrastructure (PKI)
docs.text: A framework consisting of standards and services to enable secure communication.

docs.title: Quantum bit (Qubit)
docs.text: A fundamental unit of quantum information used in quantum computing, leveraging principles of quantum physics. Unlike classical bits, which are strictly 0 or 1, qubits can exist in both states simultaneously. When measured, a qubit resolves to either 0 or 1, with the outcome determined probabilistically based on its quantum state. Qubits enable quantum computers to store, process, and transmit data in ways that differ fundamentally from classical systems.

docs.title: Root certificate
docs.text: Certificate for the highest public key in a certificate hierarchy. Root certificates are self-signed and serve as the foundation of trust in the hierarchy. Root certificates from major Certificate Authorities (CAs) are commonly preinstalled in the trust stores of web browsers and operating systems, enabling trust in the identity of a public key owner.

docs.title: (Certificate) Revocation
docs.text: Process of revoking a previously issued certificate, typically due to potential private key compromise or inaccuracies in the certificate’s data, such as a change in domain ownership.

docs.title: Salt
docs.text: A random value added to a password or input before hashing to ensure that identical inputs produce unique hashes. Salts protect against attacks like dictionary or rainbow table attacks by making hashed values harder to precompute and match.

docs.title: Self-signed certificate
docs.text: A certificate signed by the private key corresponding to its own public key, rather than being authenticated by a trusted third party. As a result, it does not provide any guarantee of authenticity.

docs.title: Security strength
docs.text: A number associated with the amount of resources (such as the number of operations, or amount of memory) required to break a cryptographic algorithm or system for a given key length.

docs.title: Shared secret
docs.text: A secret value known to two or more parties, often used as input to a key-derivation method to produce (shared) secret keys.

docs.title: Secret key
docs.text: A cryptographic key used in symmetric cryptography. It does not require additional key derivation. The secret key must be kept confidential.

docs.title: Secret keying material
docs.text: Synonym: Shared secret

docs.title: Signing (digital signatures)
docs.text: The act of creating a digital signature for a data object.

docs.title: SOX (Sarbanes-Oxley Act)
docs.text: A U.S. federal law aimed at enhancing corporate governance and accountability. It requires public companies to ensure accurate financial reporting, conduct independent audits, and implement effective internal controls. These obligations include safeguarding the integrity of relevant financial and operational data.

docs.title: Static analysis
docs.text: A method of examining an application’s code without executing it to identify potential security vulnerabilities, such as hard-coded cryptographic values or weak algorithms.

docs.title: Stream cipher
docs.text: A type of symmetric encryption that generates a continuous keystream to encrypt data one bit or byte at a time, rather than in blocks (contrast with block cipher).

docs.title: Strong Existential Unforgeability under Chosen Message Attack (SUF-CMA)
docs.text: A security property for digital signature schemes. Beyond the guarantees of EUF-CMA, where adversaries cannot forge signatures even with access to valid signatures for chosen messages, SUF-CMA ensures that adversaries cannot modify or tweak an existing valid signature in any way that it remains valid.

docs.title: Symmetric cryptography
docs.text: A type of cryptography where the same cryptographic key, called a secret key, is used for both encryption and decryption, or message authentication and verification. It is efficient for securing large amounts of data, but both parties must securely share the secret key in advance. For historical reasons, this term often is meant to also cover cryptographic hash functions, key derivation functions, and other similar key-less cryptographic algorithms.

docs.title: TLS/SSL
docs.text: Protocols used to secure data transmitted over a network by encrypting and authenticating the connection between a client and server. TLS (Transport Layer Security) is the modern, secure successor to the insecure SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) and is widely used to ensure data confidentiality, integrity, and authentication in web traffic.

docs.title: Verification (digital signatures)
docs.text: The act of confirming the validity of a digital signature for a data object.

docs.title: VPN (Virtual Private Network)
docs.text: A logical network that simulates the properties of a closed local area network, enabling secure communication between remote participants or network segments over public Internet connections. Traffic is protected using cryptographic protocols like IPSec, TLS, or WireGuard.

docs.title: Inventory
docs.text:
Select Inventory from the main menu to view detailed, itemized lists of your discovered cryptography.

The tabs organize your cryptography by:

  • Keys - cryptographic keys used to perform operations, such as encryption, decryption, and authentication.
  • Certificates - digital certificates used to establish secure communication and verify identities.
  • Operations - cryptographic operations performed, such as encryption, decryption, signing, and verification.
  • Handshakes - processes to establish a secure connection between networked applications.
  • Secrets - non-standard or user-defined objects retrieved from an external data source.

The following sections provide details for each tab.

docs.title: Keys
docs.text:
The Keys tab provides a comprehensive view of the keys within your cryptography inventory, including the following information for each:

  • Type - the algorithm used to generate the key, such as RSA, DSA, DH, etc.
  • Length - the length of the key, in bits (1024, 2048, etc.)
  • Has private key - indicates whether the key has an associated private key.
  • Last scanned - the date and time of the most recent scan where the object was found (MM/DD/YYYY HH:MM:SS AM/PM), based on the time zone set in your browser, with system time in UTC.
  • Data sources - the data sources used to discover the associated inventory object.
  • Severity - when applicable, indicates the degree of non-compliance with policy as determined by the rule used for analysis.

Use the filters at the top of the table to filter by key Type, key Length, issue Severity, or Last scanned date and time.

docs.title: Key details
docs.text:
To view more detailed information about a specific key, select Details. The details panel provides additional insights, including associated:

  • Locations
  • Issues
  • Certificates
  • Operations
  • Hosts
  • Apps
  • Container images
  • Sessions

To access a JSON object containing all key metadata, scroll to the bottom of the panel and select View full key.

docs.title: Certificates
docs.text:
The certificate inventory is summarized in the Certificates tab, which includes the following information:

  • Subject - the entity that this certificate represents, e.g. web site, application, individual.
  • Issuer - the authority that issued the certificate.
  • Valid until - the certificate expiration date.
  • Validity period - the certificate validity period.
  • Digest algorithm - the hash function used.
  • Last scanned - the date and time of the most recent scan where the object was found (MM/DD/YYYY HH:MM:SS AM/PM), based on the time zone set in your browser, with system time in UTC.
  • Data sources - the data sources used to discover the associated inventory object.
  • Severity - when applicable, indicates the degree of non-compliance with policy as determined by the rule used for analysis.

Use the filters at the top of the table to filter by certificate Subject, certificate Issuer, issue Severity, or Last scanned date and time.

docs.title: Certificate details
docs.text:
To view more detailed information about a specific certificate, select Details. The details panel provides additional insights, including associated:

  • Locations
  • Issues
  • Keys
  • Handshakes
  • Hosts
  • Apps
  • Container images
  • Sessions

To access a JSON object containing all certificate metadata, scroll to the bottom of the panel and select View full certificate.

docs.title: Operations
docs.text:
The Operations tab provides a comprehensive view of the cryptographic operations discovered during analysis, including the following information:

  • Type - the cryptographic operation performed.
  • Timestamp - the date and time of the operation (MM/DD/YYYY HH:MM:SS AM/PM), based on the time zone set in your browser, with system time in UTC.
  • Algorithms - the algorithm used, such as AES, RSA, HMAC, etc.
  • Last scanned - the date and time of the most recent scan where the object was found (MM/DD/YYYY HH:MM:SS AM/PM), based on the time zone set in your browser, with system time in UTC.
  • Data sources - the data sources used to discover the associated inventory object.
  • Severity - when applicable, indicates the degree of non-compliance with policy as determined by the rule used for analysis.

Note

If an operation involves multiple calls, the timestamp of the operation reflects the final call.

Use the filters at the top of the table to filter by issue Type, Severity, or Last scanned date and time.

docs.title: Operations details
docs.text:
To view more detailed information about a specific operation, select Details. The details panel provides additional insights, including associated:

  • Stack trace
  • Issues
  • Keys
  • Hosts
  • Apps
  • Container images
  • Sessions

To access a JSON object containing all operations metadata, scroll to the bottom of the panel and select View full operation.

docs.title: Handshakes
docs.text:
The Handshakes tab provides details about the negotiation of cryptographic parameters during data transmission:

  • Source IP - the IP address of the host that initiated the connection.
  • Target IP - the IP address of the destination host.
  • TLS Version - the version of Transport Layer Security used.
  • Selected ciphersuite - the ciphersuite selected for use in this connection.
  • Min. client TLS Version - the earliest version of TLS that the client will accept.
  • Status - whether the handshake was performed successfully or not.
  • Target port - the port number used by the target host to receive the connection.
  • Last scanned - the date and time of the most recent scan where the object was found (MM/DD/YYYY HH:MM:SS AM/PM), based on the time zone set in your browser, with system time in UTC.
  • Data sources - the data sources used to discover the associated inventory object.
  • Severity - when applicable, indicates the degree of non-compliance with policy as determined by the rule used for analysis.

Use the filters at the top of the table to filter by issue Severity, or Last scanned date and time.

docs.title: Handshake details
docs.text:
To view more detailed information about a specific handshake, select Details. The details panel provides additional insights, including associated:

  • Client supported ciphersuites
  • Client supported key exchange algorithms
  • Client supported server authentication algorithms
  • Client supported versions
  • Issues
  • Certificates
  • Sessions

To access a JSON object containing all handshake metadata, scroll to the bottom of the panel and select View full handshake. An ‘UNKNOWN’ value in a handshake indicates AQG was unable to translate a numerical identifier (NID) due to missing data, a non-standard NID, or a recently introduced NID.

docs.title: Secrets
docs.text:
The Secrets tab displays an inventory of non-standard or user-defined objects retrieved from an external data source.

  • Type - the secret type.
  • Last scanned - the date and time of the most recent scan where the object was found (MM/DD/YYYY HH:MM:SS AM/PM), based on the time zone set in your browser, with system time in UTC.
  • Data sources - the data sources used to discover the associated inventory object.
  • Severity - when applicable, indicates the degree of non-compliance with policy as determined by the rule used for analysis.

Use the filters at the top of the table to filter by issue Severity, or Last scanned date and time.

docs.title: Secrets details
docs.text:
To view more detailed information about a specific operation, select Details. The details panel provides additional insights, including associated:

  • Locations
  • Issues
  • Hosts
  • Apps
  • Container images
  • Sessions

To access a JSON object containing all secrets metadata, scroll to the bottom of the panel and select View full secret.

docs.title: Issues
docs.text:
When AQtive Guard analyzes data, it evaluates detected cryptographic objects against the currently active rules. If an object fails to meet the defined rule parameters, an issue is generated.

Issues alert you to potential security risks or compliance violations, enabling you to take prompt action to address deviations from your organization’s cryptographic standards and ensure the continued security and integrity of your data.

docs.title: View issues
docs.text:
Select Issues from the main menu to view a full list of issues discovered during analysis. The columns organize issues by:

  • Rule - The out-of-policy rule that was flagged in analysis.

  • Severity - The severity of the issue, as determined by parameters set in the associated rule. Issue severity is categorized as:

  • Occurrences - Indicates the number of cryptographic objects impacted by the issue.
  • Details - Opens AQG Knowledge Base information about the rule that triggered the issue. Refer to Knowledge base for details.

docs.title: Knowledge base
docs.text:
When reviewing issues in AQtive Guard, you can access several resources to help you understand and address the problem.

Select Details at the end of an issue row to open AQG Knowledge Base information about the rule that triggered the issue:

  1. Rule summary - A brief description of the violated rule, along with high-level recommendations for remediation.
  2. How to resolve - Guidance on how to resolve the issue.
  3. Risk factors - An overview of the potential risks associated with the issue, enabling you to assess your exposure and prioritize remediation efforts.
  4. References - Links to in-depth articles that offer up-to-date cryptographic guidance and authoritative resources.
  5. Specifications - Specifications for the rule pass/fail policy and severity criteria.

Tip

The AQtive Guard knowledge base is a valuable resource for report writing, recommendation guidance, or issue logging. You can browse and search all rules, reference articles, and the glossary at any time by selecting User guide in the menu panel.

docs.title: IT assets
docs.text:
Select IT Assets from the main menu to view details about the scanned hosts, images, and applications that contribute to your cryptography inventory.

The tabs organize your scanned IT assets by:

  • Hosts - physical laptops and servers.
  • Apps - applications.
  • Container images - images of physical or virtual networks.

The following sections provide details for each tab.

docs.title: Hosts
docs.text:
The Hosts tab provides an overview of your scanned laptops and servers, including:

  • Name - the default or user-assigned name of the scanned host.
  • OS - Operating System (Windows, Cygwin or Unix)
  • Last scanned - the date and time of the most recent scan where the object was found (MM/DD/YYYY HH:MM:SS AM/PM), based on the time zone set in your browser, with system time in UTC.
  • Data sources - the scan data sources.

Use the filters at the top of the table to filter by OS or Last scanned date and time.

docs.title: Host details
docs.text:
Selecting Details provides an in-depth view of the cryptography discovered on the associated host, including:

  • Keys
  • Certificates
  • Operations
  • Secrets
  • Sessions

Within the details panel, you can also select View full host to access a JSON object containing all host metadata.

docs.title: Apps
docs.text:
The Apps tab presents information about scanned applications, including:

  • Name - the application name, as provided by the data source. For application data uploaded from CBOM, this is the user-provided name of the application or codebase that this CBOM data belongs to, typically referencing the root name of the codebase.
  • Language - the programming language used for the application, as provided by the CBOM or the tool used to scan the application.
  • Last scanned - the date and time of the most recent scan where the object was found (MM/DD/YYYY HH:MM:SS AM/PM), based on the time zone set in your browser, with system time in UTC.
  • Data sources - the scan data sources.

Use the filters at the top of the table to filter by the Last scanned date and time.

docs.title: App details
docs.text:
Selecting Details provides an in-depth view of the cryptography discovered in the application, including:

  • Keys
  • Certificates
  • Operations
  • Secrets
  • Sessions

Within the details panel, you can also select View full application to access a JSON object containing all application metadata.

docs.title: Container images
docs.text:
The Container images tab displays the following information for scanned container images:

  • Image ID - the name assigned to the image at creation, as supplied by the data source.
  • Repository - the storage location of the container image, such as a Git repository.
  • Layer SHA - the hash or digest for the scanned container layer.
  • Last scanned - the date and time of the most recent scan where the object was found (MM/DD/YYYY HH:MM:SS AM/PM), based on the time zone set in your browser, with system time in UTC.
  • Data sources - the scan data sources.

Use the filters at the top of the table to filter by the Last scanned date and time.

docs.title: Container image details
docs.text:
Selecting Details provides an in-depth view of the cryptography discovered in the associated image, including:

  • Keys
  • Certificates
  • Operations
  • Secrets
  • Sessions

Within the details panel, you can also select View full container to access a JSON object containing all container metadata.

docs.title: Login & user roles
docs.text: This section provides instructions for logging into AQtive Guard and managing user roles.

docs.title: AQtive Guard login
docs.text:
Access the AQtive Guard web application at: your-domain.aqtiveguard.sandboxaq.com

Note

If you need help with AQG access, contact your AQG system administrator or visit our support portal.

docs.title: Assigning user roles
docs.text:
AQtive Guard integrates with your organization’s Identity Provider (IdP) to manage user configuration, including roles and access permissions. This means that user accounts and their associated roles are defined and controlled externally, through your existing IdP, rather than within AQtive Guard itself.

The following sections outline the different user roles available in AQtive Guard, the permissions associated with each role, and the specific access granted to each.

docs.title: User roles and permissions
docs.text:
An AQtive Guard user can be assigned one of the following roles and permissions:

  • Admin - has full access and capabilities in AQtive Guard.
  • Uploader - the ability to upload data generated using an AQtive Guard sensor or supported external file format.
  • Read only - has read-only access to limited pages in AQtive Guard.

The following sections provide details for the access granted for each role.

docs.title: Admin
docs.text:
Users assigned the Admin role have full access to AQtive Guard. Administrators can:

  • Perform system configuration in Settings.
  • Configure integrations.

docs.title: Read-only
docs.text:
Users assigned the Read-only user role can view content on the following pages:

  • Dashboard
  • Inventory
  • IT Assets
  • Rules (only list view; can’t create/modify/delete rules)
  • Issues

Note

To limit access to sensitive user and company data, users assigned the Read-only role can’t access Settings.

docs.title: Uploader
docs.text: Uploader users can upload a supported file format, such as CBOM or PCAP, or a trace generated using an AQtive Guard sensor.

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text: The navigation panel, located on the left side of the screen, is your central hub for accessing AQG features and resources.

docs.title: Navigation panel
docs.text:
The navigation panel has two main sections:

  1. Main menu - Access AQG features, explore your cryptographic inventory, and configure system settings.

  2. Help center - Get answers to questions or learn more about your cryptography.

docs.title: Main menu options
docs.text:
The main menu makes it easy to navigate to the following options from anywhere in AQG:

  • Dashboard - Monitor and control your cryptography using this comprehensive dashboard.
  • Inventory - Examine your cryptographic inventory by object type (keys, certificates, operations, handshakes, or secrets).
  • IT Assets - Monitor scanned hosts, applications, and container images.
  • Rules - Create and manage the rules used in analysis to identify out of policy issues.
  • Issues - Understand and address the out-of-policy issues discovered in analysis.
  • Data sources - Track scan requests and progress.
  • Settings - System admins can create API tokens with either administrator or uploader-level permissions.

Tip

For more information on each menu option, refer to the corresponding section in the user guide menu.

docs.title: Help center
docs.text:
The help center at the bottom of the AQG navigation panel offers access to AQG documentation and resources for mastering cryptographic best practices.

Select User guide to access the:

  • User guide - Browse this comprehensive guide to learn how to use AQG effectively and maximize its value.
  • Cryptography glossary - Consult this reference for clear definitions of key terms and concepts related to cryptography.
  • Rules reference - Refer to this detailed guide for information on the cryptographic rules used by AQtive Guard to identify priority issues.
  • Knowledge base - Visit the knowledge base for in-depth articles, expert guidance, and links to authoritative resources on cryptography best practices.

If you have further questions or need additional help, visit our support portal.

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
In AQtive Guard, rules define the criteria for cryptographic analysis. When data is ingested, the system checks the detected cryptography against the active rules. When a rule violation is detected, the corresponding issue is assigned a status and logged in the Issues table for further review and tracking.

Tip

To ensure effective risk management and compliance, collaborate with your organization’s security and compliance teams to verify that the rule logic is aligned with your organization’s security policies and relevant industry regulations. This alignment helps guarantee that AQtive Guard issue identification and severity categorization accurately reflects your organization’s risk tolerance and compliance requirements.

docs.title: View active rules
docs.text:
Navigate to Rules from the main menu to view the available rules for your organization. The table may contain two types of rules:

  1. Built-in AQG rules. Refer to the Rules reference in this user guide for detailed information about AQG rules.
  2. Custom rules configured by your organization.

Navigate to Rules from the main menu to view the available rules for your organization.

Refer to the Rules reference in this user guide for detailed information about AQG rules.

docs.title: Rule details
docs.text:
Select Details at the end of a rule row to view the rule reference.

Each rule reference includes:

  • A brief description of the issue and its potential impact.
  • Guidance on how to resolve the issue.
  • Links to in-depth articles in our Knowledge Base for further learning and context.
  • Information on relevant compliance and regulatory requirements.
  • Explanations of the security risks and potential consequences of not addressing the issue.
  • References to industry-recognized standards and best practices.
  • Specifications for the rule pass/fail policy and severity criteria.

docs.title: Copy a rule
docs.text: Select Copy at the end of a rule row to edit the rule AQL. Refer to Rule copy for details on copying and editing a rule.

docs.title: Settings
docs.text:
Admins can create tokens for working with the AQtive Guard API. There are two token types available, with each corresponding to a specific user role and associated privileges:

  • Uploader token - Authenticates uploads of data generated using an AQtive Guard sensor or supported external file format.
  • Admin token - Grants full administrator privileges for configuring data sources and automation using the AQG API.

Refer to Assigning user roles for more information about user roles and privileges.

docs.title: Important Security Considerations
docs.text:
Sharing Admin tokens poses a significant security risk to your AQtive Guard configuration and data. Admin tokens provide unrestricted access to your account, allowing the holder to:

  • Create and modify configurations.
  • Set up automation.
  • Access sensitive data.

To maintain the security and integrity of your AQtive Guard account:

  • Protect all tokens as confidential.
  • Only share Admin tokens with trusted administrators who have a legitimate need for full access.
  • Ensure that all tokens are properly managed and revoked when no longer needed.

docs.title: Create an API token
docs.text:
To create an AQG API token:

  1. Log in to AQtive Guard as an administrator.
  2. In Settings, select Create Uploader token or Create Admin token.
  3. Copy and securely save the token before closing the page.

Note

The token will not be displayed again for security reasons.
